direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps comes to a low point in the darkness, shining her light on a lake of salt water sloshing against the bulkhead. She kneels. As the water sloshes back she sees that it is leaking in through the seams in the steel plate of the hull.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps pulls herself onto the deck from below. She stands on a rusting 5000 ton tank barge being pulled in the open ocean by a brawny marine tug at the end of a 150 foot tow cable. It is a typical summer day in the southern Bering Sea, which means a healthy chop and a stiff cold breeze out of the north- west.  She closes the hatch behind her and makes her way forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Up ahead, the tug pulls steadily, grey-black clouds of diesel smoke rising from its massive turbine vents. Epps cinches and checks her body harness, focused and professional. The product of a rocky childhood in the Pacific Northwest and a few years of hard living, she's found her true calling now. And under some grime, several polypro shirts and a pair of orange men's Insulite pants she might even be considered pretty. She clips her harness into the tow cable where it attaches to a heavy pair of eye cleats at the bow. She climbs onto the cable, hanging out over the water as it breaks on the bow beneath her. She pulls herself forward on a roller bearing that fits over the width of the cable and starts off toward the tug at the other end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY DODGE and GREER look on from the stern, where the boat's name "Arctic Warrior" is emblazoned on the transom. Dodge (37), scruffy chief engineer, wearing de rigueur greasy coveralls and nicotine stained fingers, is an expatriate Texan and former merchant marine. GREER (42), is the boat's first mate, African American, originally from some sweltering red-neck hellhole, now a tug pilot intentionally well to the north. They watch as Epps pulls herself toward them, the cable occasionally dipping a few feet with a spray of water as a passing swell slackens it. Epps pulls herself to the stern where the cable winds into a tow anchor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a slow leak. She unclips and drops to the deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's slow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe twenty gallons an hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amidships starboard at the beam. Just under the waterline. I don't think it's a problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear that, Dodge? Epps don't think it's a problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll sleep good tonight knowing that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The view from the pilothouse commands 360 degrees as radar and GPS navigation displays glow. MURPHY, the ship's master, pilots the boat. He is 48, at sea all his adult life, and most of the rest, a fact written on his face and one that every crewman who's ever worked for him has been willing to bet his life on. A walkie-talkie CRACKLES AWAKE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer to Murphy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go. Murphy turns back to see Greer, Epps, and Dodge looking up at him from the stern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number nine on the starboard side's half flooded. Epps says it's a slow leak just under the waterline, about twenty gallons an hour. They must've pumped it before we left Sitka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course they did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let the buyer beware.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you say, Dodge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it started out at twenty an hour the piece of shit'd be at the bottom of the Gulf by now. Whether it'll make St. Lawrence is anybody's guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the Arctic Warrior pulls the barge against the swell of a grey ocean and a darkening sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAWRENCE ISLAND - DAY The shores of St. Lawrence Island open into a small port town of mainly pre-fab buildings as the Arctic Warrior approaches with the barge, now pathetically listing to one side as it moves into the harbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY A smaller harbor tug helps the Arctic Warrior jockey the listing barge to the dock as Epps and Dodge jump off to tie her up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Greer feathers the tug into position and shuts down the turbines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy jumps down from the pilothouse to the deck as a fat Russian man, Vasili (60) and a MECHANIC in grease-covered orange coveralls approach from the dock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you say Tuesday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better late than never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got a leak in the number nine compartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. You got leak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You pump it out and re-seam the hull, she'll be good as new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That cost me twenty grand at least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen, at the most.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty. You knock off twenty and then we see. After my guy looks at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a prefab office with a view of the shipyard, Vasili cuts a check as Murphy and Greer look on. He tears it out of the book, handing it across the desk to Murphy, who inspects it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want fair pay, make hamburger for Mickey D. Otherwise, please to sign. Vasili pushes a transfer register toward him. Murphy signs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer and Murphy walk back toward the dock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad for dragging a leaky tub half way to Russia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll sell the scrap for three times what he paid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must be in the wrong business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got that right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better than "making hamburger for Mickey D."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A typical port town bar. Except this one is on an island in the middle of the Bering Sea. Epps lines up a shot at the pool table as a couple of SEAMEN check out her ass and a tattoo of Wiley Coyote poking out of her pants. Greer reads a paper near-by. Murphy enters, crossing to the bar where Dodge nurses a beer and a cigarette. Murphy throws down an envelope with Dodge's name on it. Dodge picks it up, thumbs through a thick stack of hundreds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much obliged, skipper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT The place is a little more crowded now as Epps pushes her way through to the bar, a cigarette dangling from her mouth. She buys two beers and pays the BARTENDER from her envelope of cash. She takes the beers back to the far wall where a young off-duty COASTGUARDSMAN stands. He takes one, they laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beers, cigarettes and pay envelopes on the table before them, Dodge, Greer and Murphy look on at Epps across the room, who is showing the coastguardsman a birthmark on her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like Epps' gonna get some tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that coxswain dickhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You aren't jealous, are you Dodge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you kidding me? Jealous? Epps? Gimme a break. Greer and Murphy trade looks as Dodge raises his beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: can be heard as they sit there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll show you, bitch! They look over to see the coastguardsman's GIRLFRIEND, late 20s, hefty in a red miniskirt and big hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to mess with me, I'll kick your bitch ass, girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps coolly puts out her cigarette as a circle has gathered around her and the girlfriend, anxious to see a girl fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you're talking about. I just bought this guy a beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This "guy" is my man, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darlene -- GIRLFRIEND You, shut up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, I don't want any trouble, okay -- ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-uh. No. We're gonna fix this right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What seems to be the trouble, ladies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whyn't you mind your own business, chief. Murphy turns to see a shipyard RIVETER, a big man holding a beer, still wearing his welding leathers. Murphy turns back to Epps and the Girlfriend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I said, what seems to be the trouble?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you hear me, grandpa? Or you got your hearing aid turned down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you. But I'm choosing to ignore you. Epps, let's go. Epps starts forward but the Riveter stands in her way, taking Murphy by the collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These ladies was having themselves a discussion and you're interrupting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got about two seconds to get your paws off me, Tarzan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or what? Or WHACK! Murphy can't help but wince as a pool cue breaks in two over the Riveter's head. Dodge, cigarette in his mouth, takes a look at the cue half he still holds, shaking his head. The Riveter's hands fall from Murphy's collar and his legs buckle. Some of his BUDDIES hold him up as Greer reminds some of the others he's holding a pool cue of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps? He looks to Epps like let's get the hell out of here. She grabs her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. Epps holds there as the Coastguardsman steps up to his girlfriend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darlene. It's over. He gives her the ring from his finger. Murphy rolls his eyes as the others look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't love you anymore. Darlene breaks into tears as they all look on, some pat her on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Candy. Let's get out of here. The Coastguardsman takes her by the hand. Epps looks to Murphy and the others as he leads her out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy, Greer, and Dodge ready the tug to leave as Epps approaches on the dock. She jumps down onto the deck, a spring in her step and a song in her heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning everybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Show your tatoos to that coxswain last night, did you Epps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Showed him a hell of a lot more than that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Candy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my pen name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy throttles up the turbines and backs the tug away from the dock as Greer studies the dawn sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red sky at night, sailor's delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red sky in morning, sailor take warning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the tug turns into the harbor channel, the sun rising under a cloud bank of brilliant red and orange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge and Epps play cards at the galley table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck it. He puts down his hand. Epps takes another drag from her cigarette, collecting her winnings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One more?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not. She gathers the cards, shuffles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is your first name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It just occurred to me I don't know your first name. All this time and I don't know it. She deals the cards in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maureen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maureen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maureen? She looks on at him as he holds there, takes his cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's yours? Dodge takes a drag from his cigarette, thinking about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. She wants to laugh, but only studies her cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think that's funny
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. She takes a hit from her cigarette as she plays her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the tug plows westward through a steady chop and a mild swell.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: NIGHT THE SONG "SOS" BY ABBA BLASTS

direction.raw_text: The MUSIC COMES FROM HERE. Greer has the CD player cranked as he mans the helm in the glow of the pilothouse. He checks the radar, holds there a beat. He turns the MUSIC DOWN and picks up a walkie-talkie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer to Murphy. Greer studies the radar display as he waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a large vessel out about ten miles to the north-west.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy sits at his desk over the ship's log, holding his radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I been watching it for close to an hour and it hasn't moved. I can't raise it on the radio either. Makes me think it might be in trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. I'll be right up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT CLOSE ON RADAR DISPLAY as the sweep-refresh reveals a bright point of light in the middle of nowhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merchant vessel at position one seven four one five west, five seven seven five north. Murphy holds the radio mic as Greer looks on, Epps and Dodge standing back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero niner two. Over. Only the quiet hiss of white noise comes back from the radio speaker as the bright point flashes on the radar screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merchant vessel at one seven four one five west, five seven seven five north, this is tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero niner two. Over. Again, only white noise comes back as the point flashes on the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too deep to anchor out there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like it's adrift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could be a fishing boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too big. More like a freighter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell would a freighter be doing up here? It's way out of the lanes. There's not a port for 800 miles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smugglers maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuggling what? Tundra grass? A beat as Murphy holds there. He raises the radio mic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merchant vessel at position one seven four one five west, five seven seven five north, this is tugboat Arctic Warrior. Do you copy? Over. Again, only the quiet hiss of static comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call the Coastguard?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steer to one eight five. Let's check her out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Arctic Warrior cuts a foamy break in the ink black water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the phantom point flashes closer. Murphy looks on as Greer pilots, Dodge and Epps watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Back it off. Greer throttles back and the boat slows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit the lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The halogen flood lights flare to life, brilliantly illuminating the water in front of the boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The four of them look intently into the darkness beyond the light. Murphy reaches for the spot control, sweeping a broad beam of light with a joy stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the tug moves along, servo motors sweep the searchlight over the bow of the boat and into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They peer into the night beyond the boat as it slowly moves, when a shadow looms into view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, whoa. Greer throttles down all the way and they drift, as the shadow looms bigger before them in the light from the boat. As they approach, the shadow appears to be a giant rusting bow, rising up from the water, disappearing in the darkness above them. Murphy sweeps the searchlight to reveal more of what appears to be a large, darkened ship. As they come around, the name "CHIMERA" can be seen above the anchor alleys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Chimera." Murphy reaches for the mic, hits the LOUD HAILER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tug is dwarfed by the massive rusting hulk of the Chimera rising above it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is civilian tugboat Arctic Warrior. Is there anyone aboard? The quiet rumble of the tug's turbines is the only sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy raises the mic again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chimera, I am hove to at your port bow. Is there anyone aboard? They wait, looking on at the silent, darkened ship under the glare of their lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps, come with me. You guys sit tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Epps and Murphy, in heavy parkas, climb a hydraulic deck crane up to the Chimera as Dodge man's the controls against the movement of the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer holds the tug steady as Epps and Murphy can be seen making their way up under the floodlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - NIGHT Murphy pulls himself up and jumps down onto the deck. Epps jumps down behind him. Murphy throws his light up on the superstructure. All remnants of paint have been rusted over, lending a still darker ominousness to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - NIGHT Murphy and Epps move cautiously along, shining their lights as they go. Despite the omnipresent corrosion, everything seems to be in order. The decks are clear and there is no apparent damage. They come to a hatchway. Epps shines her light down the darkened passage. Murphy moves in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy and Epps move down the passageway. Even the walls in here are rusted. They come to a flight of stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer and Dodge wait. Greer reaches for his radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to me, skipper. After a moment, Murphy comes back on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're in a stairwell just under the main superstructure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy and Epps climb the darkened stairway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is definitely an old boat, maybe sixty years old. She hasn't been in service for at least twenty years. Probably a lot longer. They top the stairs and walk into a wider passageway which takes them into an open area. Their lights shine around them, revealing sinks and counters and racks of old kitchen equipment, a few pots still hanging. They move through the galley and into another, narrower, passageway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer and Dodge look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Besides a little rust, everything's pretty well-preserved. Greer and Dodge look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How she got out here is one hell of a good question. (a long beat, then) Jesus. Dodge and Greer hold there, waiting. Only silence from the other end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy. No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy, goddamit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. Another beat in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy and Epps stand at the top of a stairway, looking over an immense ballroom. Murphy raises his radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a passenger ship. It's a damn passenger ship. Though it is dark, there is enough light to see its ornate opulence, tables and chairs in place near a large dance floor and orchestra well, and a magnificent crystal chandelier hanging over it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps and Murphy climb down the deck crane as Greer and Dodge meet them at the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nobody on that boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge, Epps, Greer and Murphy sit around the galley table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably slipped her moorings, got tangled up in a current.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out here? What, so a seven hundred foot passenger liner drifted out of Spokane harbor and nobody managed to bump into her until now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody's probably looking for her as we speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever the reason, she's adrift and abandoned. We've got every right to salvage her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean tow her back? That's a thirty thousand ton ship you're talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've done it before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, from one side of the harbor to the other. But we got half the Bering Sea and the whole Alaskan gulf to drag her over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have any idea how much a ship like that could be worth in salvage? The fittings alone could go for a few million.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you get it back in one piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a risk I'm willing to take.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All we got to do is hit some rough weather and you can forget about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we cut her loose and wait it out. A little weather couldn't be anything she hasn't seen before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a bloody navigation hazard. One boat can't control a ship that size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The damn thing's been floating around for God knows how long and it hasn't hit anything yet. So we take it easy. A little of the old push pull. A long beat as they hold there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen. Forget this job's just a pay check for a minute. You know I've been good to you. But I'm prepared to offer you something better now. (a beat) If we do this right, it's worth a lot of money. A lot of money. They hold there looking on at him, waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salvage fees on a vessel like this could come in around four million bucks. At least. Who knows, could be more. Could be a lot more. (a beat) What I'm proposing is... we split it four ways. A beat. Dodge looks to Epps and Greer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think about it. A million bucks a piece. (a beat) You want to spend the rest of your days drag-assing tank barges on the gulf coast, fine. Otherwise, let's get to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tug is tied up alongside the Chimera, whose dark hull stretches off for seven hundred more feet in the light of day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy brings up the radio mic as Greer and the others look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: United States Coastguard, United States Coastguard, United States Coastguard. This is tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero niner two. Over. After a moment, a distance-warped, coolly professional, female voice comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coastguard Station North Island. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North Island, I wish to declare myself salvor-in-posession under section four two charlie of the International Maritime Convention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. What type of vessel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A passenger liner. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say again. Over. Murphy looks to the others, almost smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A passenger liner, north island. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is the vessel name, registry, and present position? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Passenger vessel "Chimera." I will spell: charlie hotel india mary echo romeo alpha. No registry information is available at this time. I have determined to the best of my ability that the vessel has been abandoned on the high seas at position one seven four west, five seven north at... (checking his watch) Two zero one four hours zulu time. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. Please advise your salvage authority pending registry check. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger, North Island. Arctic Warrior over and out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge, Epps, Murphy and Greer are standing on the stern of the boat under the power winch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. We're gonna use a heavier than usual twin cable rig this time, consisting of a pair of number three gauge braided wire tows. (a beat) We'll tie off through the anchor alleys. And come down to the aft port and starboard pins. Here.  Thus, we need to get two of these... (indicating the cable) Up there. He indicates the bow of the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing as though a foot of one of these fuckers weighs about a hundred pounds, it ain't gonna be what you'd call easy. (a beat) Any questions?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Supposing one of those cables breaks under tow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we'll all be doomed. Any other questions?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy has backed the tug up to the bow of the Chimera. Greer operates the deck crane, one of Dodge's mammoth cables dangling from it down to the winch on the stern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps hangs on to the top of the crane as it comes to the starboard anchor alley in the bow of the Chimera. Dodge pokes his face out from the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring it on, dude. Dodge disappears from the hole and his hand comes back with a smaller pilot cable, which Epps takes and threads through the loop at the end of the tow cable. She places the end of the pilot cable in a vice collar and uses a wrench to tighten it down, with the effect of joining the two cables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Dodge disappears, pulling up the slack from the pilot cable through the anchor alleys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit it! Epps reaches over and unhinges the crane hook and the tow cable explosively drops, banging loudly against the Chimera's hull with a shower of black rust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge cranks a portable pulley winch on the deck, the pilot cable slowly pulling the tow cable up through the anchor alley. It is heavy and the winch shows the strain as Dodge cranks it. He continues, when something gives in the winch mechanism and the whole thing slides forward on the pilot cable, entangling Dodge's leg and dragging him on his ass along the deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tow cable creates a spray of rust and smoke as it spills out of the anchor alley before Epps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge slides toward the anchor alley like a piece of meat toward a sausage grinder, when the winch slams into it and stops dead, the cable continuing on with a loud shriek dangerously close to his face, until...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last of the cable explosively whips out of the anchor alley in front of Epps and splashes in the water below. A beat as she holds there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge? You alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge lies tangled in the winch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two tow cables extend from the Chimera's anchor alleys down into the water and come up again from the water to the tow anchor on the tug's stern. Dodge looks on as Greer and Epps stand by. He raises his walkie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright, skipper, real easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy slowly throttles up, moving the boat forward. He turns to see as the Chimera drops back behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tug moves slowly away from the Chimera as Epps, Greer and Dodge look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the tug widens the distance, leaving the Chimera in place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy holds the helm steady as the Chimera recedes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steady as she goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge, Epps and Greer look on as the tow cables begin to rise in their wake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throttle back. The tug slows as the cables rise slowly from the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More. The tug slows still more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More. It slows still more, until the tug just creeps along, and the massive tow cables rise entirely out of the water, straightening as the slack is pulled out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some fifty yards behind the tug, the tow cables come taught in the anchor alleys of the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy holds the throttle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right there, skipper. Right there. Murphy eases forward on the throttle and the turbines rise in pitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the tow cables stretch and the bow of the Chimera inches forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The turbines grow louder as Greer, Epps, and Dodge look on at the Chimera behind them, the massive tow cables bowing under their own weight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy eases forward on the throttle, picking up speed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The giant ship CREAKS AND MOANS as it starts forward, a small bow break forming on its hull.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tug is kicking up a foaming wake as it pulls the Chimera along behind it. Dodge lets out a hoot, exchanging high fives with Epps and Greer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy smiles as he looks back at the Chimera following behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The south Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska. A pencil traces a route.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I figure we go through at the Unimak Pass here. Refuel at Sanak Island. Greer looks on from the helm as Murphy, Dodge and Epps stand over the map table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a little extra fuel, weather permitting, we should make Sitka in five days without another stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds reasonable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hypothetically speaking, what if we get this boat to Sitka and find out somebody wants it back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shoulda thought of that when they let her float away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care what, ain't nobody just gonna let us walk away with a ship that size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The law's on our side. If they want to challenge it, let them try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They must've scuttled it. Nobody just lets a ship float away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody just scuttles a passenger liner either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever heard of insurance, big boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either way, we found it. It's ours now -- . An EXPLOSIVE THUD shudders the boat. They look to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: LOUD THUMP BLOWS OUT OF THE TURBINE VENTS, SHOWERING OIL OVER THE DECK

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Dodge jumps down from the pilothouse as another LOUD THUMP BLOWS OUT OF THE TURBINE VENTS, SHOWERING OIL OVER THE DECK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! ALL STOP!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer shoves the throttle back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boat goes dead in the water, thick black smoke billowing from the turbine vents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as the bow slows in the water, the tow cables coming slack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge pulls open the door. The place is thick with smoke as he makes his way to the turbine gauges, Epps and Murphy behind. Dodge opens the number one turbine cover, looks inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother fucker!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Threw a turbine blade. Dodge looks over the smoking turbine, pulls back an aluminum intake blade, hot to the touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a bitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer, Dodge, Epps, and Murphy confer on the deck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number one turbine's pretty well trashed. Number two runs, but it's way underpowered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long to fix?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard to say. I gotta get in there and have a look. At least a couple days. Depending.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think the extra strain caused it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nah. Everything was cool. It's just one of those things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Arctic Warrior floats tied to the side of the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge has both turbines opened up as he works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights shine on what was once an elegant interior promenade. Murphy and Greer stand looking on at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some classy tub in it's day, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Check this out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps looks through a file cabinet behind a heavy wood counter as Greer and Murphy approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything's still here. Ticket records, receipts, books of account. Greer picks one up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One first class passage. Elizabeth James. Dubayy to Halifax. January 29th 1953. Murphy takes it, looking it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chimera. Flag ship of the Dobbins Kirk Line. Nova Scotia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy, Epps, and Greer top a staircase out onto a long, darkened corridor. They move down. Some of the doors are open, faint light from port holes showing small cabins with beds, desks, a few chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy, Epps, and Greer come to a hatchway marked "BRIDGE."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY The forward windows show the expanse of the ocean before them and the rusting foredeck about 150 feet below. Light from the windows illuminates the bridge as Murphy, Greer and Epps look around. Despite a little corrosion and a layer of dirt, everything seems in its place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd sure like to get my hands on the general log. Epps steps up to the wall, where several framed photos hang.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That must be the old man right there. The uniformed man in the photo is a gaunt, stern-looking man from another century, with dark, hollow eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like one hell of a stick up his ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd let you off at the nearest port, that's for sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dimming purple horizon is giving way to night as the tug floats under the bow of the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge works up to his elbows in turbine 1 as Greer monitors a pressure gauge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sixty pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what it says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lemme see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the pilothouse windows, the hull of the Chimera disappears into the darkness beyond the tug's work lights. Murphy sits at the chart table as Epps steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Thanks. She brings him his cup, seeing the documents he brought back from the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you find up there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some charts. A crew manifest. (looking them over) Looks like her last voyage was January 1953. The question is where the hell's she been since.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was sailing up north, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her destination was Halifax, yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, suppose she got a little further north than she should have.  Got stuck in the ice. The passengers and crew evacuated. She froze into the ice pack, which moved further north, where it froze in solid. They write it off. Fifty years later, the whole global warming thing happens. The ice melts, she gets loose and floats around til somebody runs into her. Murphy nods, considering it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As reasonable an explanation as any, I guess. Epps takes a sip of her coffee as she thinks about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever heard of the Mary Celeste?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was a two-masted brig boat sailing out of New York in 1872.  One day she was sighted off the coast of Portugal by a merchant vessel, the Dei Gratia. As the crew of the Dei Gratia got closer, they discovered that no one was at the helm of the Mary Celeste. On boarding, they found her completely deserted. The captain, his wife, their daughter, and the entire crew, all gone. The last entry in their log made no mention of any trouble. The table was even set for dinner. And in the nine days after the last entry, she sailed 700 miles without anyone aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what did happen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody knows. There've been a lot of theories, of course. But we'll never really know for sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think she's sailing without a crew? Murphy looks out at the Chimera off the bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we'd be surprised where a drifting ship might wind up with a little wind and the right current.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're more practical than superstitious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only way to be. Epps nods, takes another sip of coffee, looking on at the rusting hull of the Chimera stretching off in the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greer operates the crane arm as Dodge directs him. The crane hoists out one of the massive turbine fans onto the deck. Dodge gives him the thumbs up as it comes down easily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turbine rotor's shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you said it was just a blade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Metal's crystallized. Gotta replace the whole deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much longer's that gonna take?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like I always say -- MURPHY I know I know, two ways to do anything -- DODGE The right way and the wrong way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We gotta get outa here, Dodge. A storm blows up and we're history.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you, you don't want to be running that fan like it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about running number two by itself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a full 2500 horses down. We couldn't drag that boat down hill on ice with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta pull the blades and re-seat everything in a new rotor -- .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three, four days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamit, Dodge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to tell you, that we can throw this sucker back in and start pulling her like nothing happened? Can't do it, skipper. A beat as Murphy stands there, knowing he's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coastguard. Over. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Murphy enters the pilothouse as the distance-warped VOICE comes back on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coastguard Station North Island. Over. Murphy raises the radio mic as Epps, Dodge, and Greer step in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North Island, North Island, North Island. This is tugboat Arctic Warrior. Over. After a moment, the same professional, distance-warped voice comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arctic Warrior, we have submitted your section four two charlie salvage notification. However, the International Maritime Authority record for a passenger vessel Chimera indicates it was lost at sea in the Gulf of Oman day two month two year one nine five three.  Over. A beat as Murphy holds there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North Island, please repeat? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arctic Warrior, passenger vessel Chimera was lost at sea day two month two year one nine five three.  Over. Another beat as Murphy holds there, as the others look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North Island, have you got any additional information? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. The vessel Chimera was registered to The Dobbins Kirk Line, Halifax.  Nova Scotia. Date of commission day nine month seven year one nine three two. Over. A long beat as the static of the open channel comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger, North Island. I am tied to the passenger vessel Chimera. And she is afloat. Repeat, she is afloat. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger, Arctic Warrior. I say again, our records indicate the passenger vessel Chimera was lost at sea. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger, North Island. Please advise pending further information. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coast Guard North Island Station. Over and out. A beat as they hold there, thinking about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Obviously it's some kind of screw up. The shipping records aren't a hundred percent accurate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man, it gives me the creeps. We got no business towing a ship that size anyway. I say we fix the turbines and hit the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you crazy? Do you realize we got ourselves a ship? We own a ship, Dodge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, a ship that's supposed to have been lost at sea fifty years ago. You don't think that's just a little freaky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If this thing turns out to be a ship everybody thought sank a long time ago, we just hit the jackpot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well how the hell you get something like that wrong? That's a damn big boat. It's either sunk or it ain't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all want to get outa here, Dodge. Especially me. With that boat in tow. You got three days.  Make the most of it. A beat as Dodge looks back, then out at the Chimera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pencil point on a map follows across Saudi Arabia, coming to the Persian Gulf and tracing the coast of the Arab Emirates to Dubayy. Murphy sits at his desk over the map. His pencil point follows the Persian Gulf from Dubayy, through the straight of Hormuz into the Gulf of Oman. Murphy marks an "X" there. A beat as he looks on at it. He opens a large envelope he found aboard the Chimera. He empties it on the desk. He looks through it, docking receipts from various ports of call, bills of lading, etc. He looks over the passenger manifest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murphy wakes. He lies on his bunk, having fallen asleep last night in his clothes, still holding the envelope and some of the papers inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Dodge disassembles the turbine fans on deck as Greer reads in the shade of the deck house. Dodge's hand slips and he skins his knuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fucker!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy, Dodge. It's only a piece of metal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn mind of it's own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, skipper. Murphy has stepped out into the sunlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're up late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guess I must've fallen back to sleep. Where's Epps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Went aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She take a radio?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Murphy nods. A beat.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FIGURE, IN MURKY SILHOUETTE, MOVE PAST THE DOORWAY IN THE BACKGROUND

direction.raw_text: Epps steps from a passageway into a large public room. Tables and chairs are scattered haphazardly, light falling in from windows along the wall where tattered curtains hang. She walks on. A pair of empty glasses sit on a table, an empty sherry decanter beside them. An ashtray sits beside that. Epps stops, reaching down. She pulls back a half-smoked cigarette, lipstick smudging the end, yellowing and fragile from time. And, as she stands there, we see a FIGURE, IN MURKY SILHOUETTE, MOVE PAST THE DOORWAY IN THE BACKGROUND. In an instant it is there and gone. She puts down the cigarette, having sensed a presence. She turns to the doorway across the room, but there is nothing to be seen now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY A doll's white face, eyes haunting and coldly blue, stares into the middle distance. It lies on a love seat as Epps steps up. She lifts it. Several other toys lie scattered about as she studies it, when the sound of a TICKING CLOCK CAN BE HEARD. A beat as Epps holds there. She turns, trying to locate the sound. From across the room, Epps stands, listening. As the TICKING CLOCK sounds from here. She turns, putting down the doll, holding a beat. She approaches, crossing the room, coming finally to a stop before us and what we come to see is an ancient grandfather clock. All but it's minute hand has fallen off its corroded face, but from inside it emits a weak though steady TICKING. Epps stands there as the clock ticks, looking on, when the TICKING CEASES. A beat as she holds there, as the clock faces her, now silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps shines her light in the darkness as she comes to a door where daylight falls from a small port. She looks through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Epps stands in a white tiled room. Light falls from port holes high in the wall. Running its length is a small swimming pool, it's rusted fixtures and stained surface creating bizarre patterns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Epps comes to a row of changing stalls. Old clothing hangs there, unused for fifty years. A pair of woman's shoes lie on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps moves along, passing through a doorway into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps enters another room scattered with old exercise equipment circa 1950, a wooden rowing machine, barbells and a medicine ball. She steps up to the wall, where pictures hang. The Chimera can be seen in better days, sailing full speed on a calm sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps jumps down to a lower deck. She shines her light up to see that she is in an engine compartment, showing a massive diesel burner. She passes through into another compartment where the giant pistons of the ship's power plant rise up to the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Epps moves, passing still more diesel burners, towering over her in the cavernous space. She moves into a narrowing passage, piping and machinery ducts winding their way into the depths of the ship. Finally the passage opens into yet another compartment, apparently a cargo hold. Crates and boxes are stacked on loading palettes. In the corner, a rotting canvas drape covers something. Epps comes to it. She lifts the canvas, which crumbles away to reveal a 1951 Ferrari sportster. For the exception of a coat of dust and a small amount of corrosion, it is perfectly preserved. Mail bags lie in piles along the wall, stacked between more wooden crates and palettes, when something catches Epps' eye. A heavy, metal door in the wall is twisted on it's hinges, as though blown back from some terrific explosive force. Epps approaches, coming to the twisted door. She shines her light inside. A clutter of debris, shelving and wood, are visible in the shadows, when her light catches a glint of something. She swings her light back, revealing a yellowish bright object between broken wood slats. Epps steps in. She kneels, shining the light closer. The yellow glint is metal. Epps pulls back a slat, sliding away some of the debris to reveal that it is cast from a kilogram ingot of gold. She reaches out. She raises it, completely untouched by the years. She pulls back still more debris, revealing a stack of gold ingots, some having tumbled to the side. She slides away a large trunk that has fallen, pushing off more junk to see that the stack is much larger, perhaps four feet high and five feet across. A beat as Epps stands there, looking on at $50,000,000 in gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The debris has been cleared away to reveal a clean 5'x 5' x 4' stack of gold ingots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck we gonna do with it? Greer, Murphy, Epps, and Dodge all look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck you think we gonna do with it? It's ours, baby. It's all ours. Murphy has stepped forward, taking an ingot, inspecting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much you figure that's worth, skipper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard to say. Maybe forty, fifty million.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ho, baby!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a lot of money for somebody to just let float away. Murphy looks up at her from the gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it is. A beat as they all hold there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a hell of a lot of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, you think there's something funny about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ship with fifty million dollars in gold aboard, adrift? And nobody seems to care enough to come looking for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they thought it was lost at sea, they probably just wrote it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for fifty million. An ocean liner maybe. But fifty million in gold, they come looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe they didn't want it back. Maybe the whole fat deal was insured.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe. But there's always somebody whose interest's at stake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I gotta say is it looks like that somebody's us right now. Greer cackles as he high fives Dodge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it looks like somebody got here before us too. The steel hatch is twisted, as from a great hand ripping it back from the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't happen yesterday, I'll tell you that. Torn parts rusted bad as the rest of the boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then it happened before they scuttled her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, before she sank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cargo like this could make a crew think twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That it could. A beat, as they all look on at the gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After dinner, Murphy, Greer, Dodge and Epps sit around the galley table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why didn't they take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably didn't have time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or somebody stopped them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either way, they must've had a pretty good reason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must be a damn good reason to jump ship and leave fifty million dollars aboard. A beat as they consider it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what're we gonna do. That's the big question, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A salvage claim to a vessel's cargo's as valid as a claim to the vessel itself. It's ours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we're rich. We're damn, filthy stinking rich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks like it. A beat as they let this sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what? We gonna unload the gold and get a move on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We leave it where it is. Stick to the plan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gotta be kidding? What the hell we need that tub for, we got fifty million bucks?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we get a little more for the boat. Besides, the gold'll be safer where it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but we still gotta haul that big piece of shit all the way back to Sitka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's worth the effort. Believe me. Besides we're gonna need her to prove the salvage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not call for help?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For now the best thing we can do is to keep quiet about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last thing we want is extra partners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or uninvited guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge, you gotta get on those repairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, yeah. I'm on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sooner we get under way, the sooner we are to spending what's ours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dodge, wearing a welding mask and gloves, braises an aluminum fitting over one of the open turbines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps finishes stacking the gold ingots in a cleared space beyond the twisted hatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hundred twenty. Two twenty one. (as Epps stacks the last one) Two twenty two. Greer makes a note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hundred twenty two kilograms of solid gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I call a payday.
direction.name: direction

Dodge grabs another extinguisher, his leg burned, face and hands singed. An EXPLOSION ROCKS THE BOAT and molten flames hurl through the air, catching Murphy's pant leg. He's so engrossed in fighting the flames, he doesn't realize he's on fire.

Fire belches from a duct, crawling across the ceiling. Dodge fires his extinguisher at it, pushing it back across to the wall again. Murphy extinguishes the last of the flames in the turbine well as Dodge brings a snaking tendril of fire down to the deck, and finally out. They stand there in the sudden silence, the air heavy with smoke. A fine layer of halon powder lies over everything, but the fire is out.

result.heading: A BLUR EXPLODES OUT AT HER

direction.raw_text: Where the propeller shaft extends into a large turbine. She continues on, past huge rusting diesel burners, disappearing into the darkness above her, when ANOTHER BOOM SOUNDS. She turns, shinning her light back from where she came. Nothing moves. Not a sound, but for her breathing and maybe her heart pounding in her chest. ANOTHER BOOM SOUNDS, again echoing distantly in the silence. She shines her light through the line of burners. Nothing moves. Epps moves quietly between the burners. She comes to a massive watertight door at the bulkhead. She steps through, finding herself standing between a row of huge oil storage tanks. THE BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN, closer, as suddenly stopping. She moves on, cautiously walking between the tanks, holding her light out before her. She comes to the end of the compartment and another bulkhead. The BOOMING SOUNDS, still closer. She turns the light into the recesses, showing rusting machinery and a stack of oil drums. She approaches, holding the shotgun up. As she nears, the BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN. She stops. It is coming from here. She tenses, raising the shotgun, holding the light as steady as she can manage. The BOOMING SOUNDS YET AGAIN. It is metallic and staccato. She stops in the corner beside an oil drum. Several drums have toppled and lie scattered in a pile when a draft stirs her hair. She shines her light up to see that she stands at the bottom of a giant hatchway shaft rising all the way through the ship to the top deck and an echoey breeze that betrays a throughway to the outside. The BOOMING SOUNDS AGAIN, this time coming from the pile of oil drums. She steps closer, raising the shotgun, ready to fire. A beat as she summons her courage, then reaches out to push a drum with her foot, when A BLUR EXPLODES OUT AT HER. She fires the shotgun and a spray of buckshot glances off the steel bulkhead in a shower of sparks, a flurry of frenetic flapping whizzing by her head as she looks up to see a large albatross flying back up the hatchway shaft toward the top of the ship and freedom.

direction.raw_text: Captain relieved of command. He holds there a moment, moving his finger down to the final entry, reading: "TRANSMISSION 2 Feb 53 21:24 hrs GMT. General SOS." He turns the page to see only the words "GOD SAVE US" scrawled in faded red ink. A beat as he holds there, when a CHANNEL OPENS WITH A SHORT BURST ON MURPHY'S RADIO. He looks to it, but there is no response from the other end. Another SHORT BURST AND THE CHANNEL OPENS AGAIN. The swell brings the crane toward the boat one last time and Dodge reaches out, his fingers just coming to the line, coaxing it into his grasp. He pulls it back and hangs on, as the crane sways back with the foundering boat. The crane falls away from Dodge, leaving him hanging in space by the line from the bow of the Chimera.

direction.raw_text: Murphy, Greer and Epps look on as Dodge hangs over the water and the tug as its stern slowly sinks beneath the waves. Dodge climbs the line toward the bow railing as the tug rolls still further to port, the pilothouse dipping into the sea, slipping lower and lower.

direction.raw_text: As he pulls himself upward, coming to the bottom of the rail well on the Chimera where Murphy reaches out, just short of Dodge's hand.

It starts sliding along the hull as the tug drifts, pulling the cable with it, toward Dodge as he dangles in mid air. Dodge pulls himself up, reaching for Murphy, but still short.

result.heading: SICKENING GRINDING SOUND OF HEAVY STEEL AGAINST STEEL

direction.raw_text: and Dodge turns to see misty air escaping from ports and deck vents as the encroaching water forces it out of the tug below decks. The tow cable LOUDLY SCRAPES THE HULL in a shower of rust, as Dodge struggles to pull himself up. Murphy reaches out as Dodge extends as far as he can, their hands barely reaching. The tow cable is a mere few feet away and closing, ready to scrape Dodge into the water or smear him across the hull like a bug on a windshield, when Dodge pulls himself up with everything he's got and Murphy grabs his hand. Murphy pulls, lifting Dodge, as Greer grabs Dodge's other hand and they pull him up, the tow cable sweeping by with a SICKENING GRINDING SOUND OF HEAVY STEEL AGAINST STEEL. Dodge turns to see the bow of the tug dip below the surface, slowly going under until disappearing with a last exhalation of misty air. The pilothouse is next to go, the last of it slipping into the frothing water, then the crane, finally disappearing altogether into the depths. A long beat as they hold there in the sudden silence, phantom bubbles rising to the surface where the tug once stood.

result.heading: MOVEMENT CAN BE HEARD SOMEWHERE BEYOND THE ENTRY

direction.raw_text: Epps scavenges for food in the semi-darkness of the large, open galley, when a MOVEMENT CAN BE HEARD SOMEWHERE BEYOND THE ENTRY separating the galley from the outer passageway.

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Epps steps into the passageway. Directly across is the entry to the swimming pool. She walks on.

direction.raw_text: Epps steps in. Light falls in from the dirty port holes at the ceiling, every movement echoing off the hard tile walls. She holds there a beat, then turns to go when she sees a GIRL of about 16 facing her on the other side of the pool. Epps holds there, as the girl only looks back. She is porcelain white, flaxen hair drawn behind her head, her clothing hanging loosely from a frail body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must leave. A beat as Epps stands there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you? From this distance and in the light it is hard to fully discern the girl's features.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's great evil here, more than you can know. Leave now or you may never leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But -- A HATCH CLOSES SOMEWHERE IN THE SHIP. Epps turns to look. When she turns back the girl is gone. A quiet "TICK" SOUND ECHOES in the pool. She looks down to see that the pool is now very, very deep, like a mine shaft falling away into the depths. And, as she stands there, dark water is quickly rising up from the bottom. She steps back as the water gradually fills the pool to the top. It is very dark and the bottom is indiscernible, when the water begins to churn, as from bubbles of air reaching the surface. Epps steps closer, looking on as a faint red glow can be seen deep in the water below the churning bubbles. As she watches, the red glow grows in intensity. The glow spreads, illuminating a broad area until it becomes clear that the water is not water at all but blood. And, as the light grows still brighter, a figure is illuminated, well below the surface as it seems to rise up. Epps looks on as the figure rises higher into the light. It is a MAN, fighting desperately to reach the surface. The bubbles that rise up are produced from his silent screams. Epps starts forward, but another figure rises to the same point, a WOMAN, also struggling. Another MAN floats up, then another, and another, people floating up, fighting desperately to reach the surface, unable to do so, drowning in blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My God.... Epps reaches out over the edge, plunging her hand into the blood, reaching for the man's hand, but they are too far apart. direction.raw_text: A file drawer comes open, revealing ticket receipts. Epps looks on at it. The receipts are labeled "FULL FARE PASSAGES" and are divided by first, second, and third class. She goes through them, coming to a section that says "ACCOMPANIED CHILDREN." She pulls out the folder, laying it on the counter, opening it. The first page is a receipt for a single passage to Halifax for a Tatterly, Stephen age: 14. She pulls it back to reveal another, Wilson, Harold age: 4. Another, Vitti, Angela age: 17. She pages through the stack, looking at the ages: 3, 15, 6, 11, 1, until coming across a 9. She looks to the name, Klein, David, a boy. She continues paging through the receipts coming to another 9. She stops, looking to the name, Nichols, Katherine age: 16. A girl. She looks to the cabin assignment: "400." She notes that it is the same cabin where Greer was found, when a REVERBERANT CONCUSSION SOUNDS THROUGH THE SHIP.

From one, she pulls back a woman's gown, a blouse. The other contains shirts, trousers, socks, and underwear. Across the room a smaller suitcase can be seen lying open on an Ottoman in the corner. Epps crosses to it. She finds a few shirts, and a red print dress, some books. She takes one of the books, opening it. Inscribed on the inside of the cover is: "This book belongs to:" and then written in by hand: "Katie Nichols." A page is marked with a purple ribbon. She opens it to see a children's poem "The Rooster and the Crow" and a drawing of a rooster and a crow and a stanza of a poem: "'Cock-a-doodle doo,' said the rooster to the crow. 'Where are you now? I know, but won't say so.'" She puts it down. A tin penny whistle sits on the table. She picks it up, examining it. She opens a small picture book, thumbing through to see photos of a family, a young mother and father at the beach, the mother and a girl of about 9 years, the girl and an older girl of about 16, the girl she saw at the swimming pool, KATIE. He speaks nonsense, his face distorted in an ugly grimace, eyes bulging as Epps fumbles over the table, a tray of glass and silver crashing to the floor as he pushes her back, still choking her. He backs her to the wall, pushing in, closing her windpipe the rest of the way. Her hand searches behind her, knocking over a small vase, a basket, some books. It comes to a brass desk lamp. It falls, a little out of reach. She is going to black out any second, as Greer strangles her. Her hand comes to the desk lamp, grabbing it. He raises a fist to ram into her face when WHAM! Epps has shoved the butt of her flashlight into his crotch and he comes up SCREAMING. He grabs her face, striking her with his other hand. She swings the flashlight again and cracks him across the head. He swings yet again and connects, knocking her across the floor. She lies in a heap as Greer climbs to his feet, enraged and bleeding. He unbuckles his belt as he approaches, pulling it from his waist to do God knows what. Epps looks around to see him approaching. And we see that she has unhinged her gill knife. As his foot steps near, she lets go and drives the knife with all her might into his boot, plunging the blade through his foot and into the floor. He SCREAMS. After a moment he stops, looks to her. He is a bloody, wretched, enraged mess. He starts toward her as Murphy appears in the doorway. Just as Greer is upon her, Murphy blind sides Greer from behind at full speed, knocking him down. Greer and Murphy struggle as Epps climbs unsteadily to her feet. She staggers to them and raises the flashlight over Greer, bringing it down on his head.

direction.name: direction

The steward looks up, reaches over and slams the door shut. She continues on. Another door stands open as she comes to it, back at room 400. She stops. A REPETITIVE SOUND CAN BE HEARD, coming from inside.

direction.raw_text: Epps steps in as the SOUND CONTINUES. She crosses the sitting room, coming to the doorway of the bedroom to find several MUTINEERS, some in stewards attire, others wearing ships officers caps, obviously taken from their rightful owners. The repetitive sound comes from here, bed springs. And, from between the men, a woman's bare legs hang over the end of the bed as a pair of man's legs in boots lie between them, the bed rocking, the others looking on. Epps turns to see the father. He is on his knees, hands tied behind his back as he is forced to watch from the foot of the bed.

direction.raw_text: a geometric pattern of a lotus on the Persian carpet at her feet. When she looks up again she sees what the father sees. The mutineer finishes, climbing off the woman. direction.raw_text: You like that, daddy? I'll show you something else now. The mutineer steps back to the bed. He sits Katie down so that she faces us on the end of the bed. He raises an axe over her, bringing it down as the world becomes a whirling blur -- EPPS (V.O.)

direction.raw_text: Epps stops where she is in the cavernous engine room, looking on at the massive hull rising above her as the RUMBLING GROWS IN INTENSITY. Though it seems to resonate throughout the ship, it seems to originate from here, from directly below, as though the hull were being dragged over a rocky bottom. She steps back as the sound grows still louder, until it becomes absolutely deafening. The ship begins to shudder. The steel bulkheads visibly move and the steel plates in the hull can be seen to bend back and forth.

direction.raw_text: Murphy slows and finally stops.

HORRENDOUS TUMULT OF NOISE AND STEAM AND SPARKS

direction.raw_text: A few rivets pop in the hull. Then a few more, as the RUMBLING GROWS STILL LOUDER. Epps puts her hands to her ears and begins to back away, when the RUMBLING REACHES A PINNACLE. The rivets are springing out of the hull like machine gun fire when the steel plate of the hull gives way, A MASSIVE CRAG OF ROCK SMASHING THROUGH WITH A TREMENDOUS BOOM AND A TORRENT OF SEAWATER. Epps ducks for cover as the crag tears a diagonal line through the Chimera's hull like a jagged claw through paper in a HORRENDOUS TUMULT OF NOISE AND STEAM AND SPARKS.

direction.raw_text: The ship is drifting free of the island with the current, a huge gash rising on its port side.

direction.raw_text: Murphy moves down the passageway, coming to the cargo compartment.

direction.raw_text: Epps comes up for air. A clatter of all manner of debris, tools and general detritus hammers against the far bulkhead as the ship eases over. A boiler breaks loose of its stays. Epps looks up to see it coming right for her. She ducks under the water as the boiler slams into the bulkhead where she was.

direction.raw_text: Epps is forced down by the boiler, trapped between it and the bulkhead.

direction.raw_text: The gold slides off the palette, crashing into the far wall. Murphy hurries to it, collecting ingots and putting them in his pockets.

direction.raw_text: Epps struggles under the water to free herself, but she is trapped, the heavy boiler and its broken stays caging her.

direction.raw_text: The level of the water has now almost completely reached the deck above, filling the ship almost entirely below decks.

direction.raw_text: The water is threateningly high as Murphy pockets one last ingot and makes his way for the exit.

direction.raw_text: Epps is trying to pull back the boiler stays, without luck. She swims down lower, finding a pipe fitting she pries at the stays, without luck, when a form drifts into view in the murky water. Several more forms appear. They are human, suspended in the water. As Epps looks, the several forms have become many. They are the bodies of the dead she saw in the pool before. As they look on at her from where they are, one form emerges. It is Katie. She reaches toward Epps, as if beckoning her to take her hand from the other side. Epps raises her hand, taking it. The girl leads Epps down into the murky darkness where she finds a way out. She takes her back further, coming to the breech, leading her out and into a cool green void of water. Katie stops at the breach. Epps turns to her. She only looks back at Epps. Epps turns away, swimming upward toward the light of the surface.

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY Epps breaks through, gasping for air. She looks to see the Chimera, listing heavily to one side, its bow decks fully awash.

direction.raw_text: Murphy staggers through the flooded passage.

direction.raw_text: The Chimera is getting lower in the water, the bow submerged and the stern beginning to rise. Epps sees another small island some distance off. She begins swimming toward it.

direction.raw_text: Water runs down the stairway as Murphy struggles toward the top.

direction.raw_text: Epps swims as the ship sinks in the distance.

direction.raw_text: A river of water rushes through as Murphy crosses with difficulty.

direction.raw_text: Epps reaches the jagged rock of the island. She pulls herself up.

direction.raw_text: Water rushes in as Murphy wades out onto the Chimera's top deck. He is heavily weighted down and periodically goes under as he half wades half swims, the length of the ship's aft portion rising above him as the bow sinks.

direction.raw_text: Epps collapses on the rocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the ship moves lower, Murphy pushes off. He bobs under momentarily, then comes back up with difficulty. The forward smoke stack has dipped under and is now taking on water, the current from the rushing water pulling him toward it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Epps looks on as the giant ship angles higher and higher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the ship dips lower, the rushing water forms an eddy that pulls at Murphy. Murphy struggles, too heavy to resist as he is pulled closer and closer to the sucking maw that is the smokestack's opening. The ship sinks further and Murphy is pulled to the edge of the stack. He frantically grabs for something to hold on to, without success, until he is finally pulled into the smoke stack and sucked into the bowels of the ship by the rushing water.

result.heading: RUMBLE OF ENGINES CAN BE HEARD

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Epps sits perched under a rock out of the wind, looking on at the Chimera, her stern rising high above water as she goes down, when the RUMBLE OF ENGINES CAN BE HEARD. She turns to see a Coastguard plane sweeping low over the Chimera, then banking back and flying right over as she shouts and waves her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY The Coastguard plane flies by one more time, this time dropping a survival pack. The Chimera's stern rises up out of the water, almost vertical now, slipping further and further under. Epps looks on one last time, as the ship goes down.
direction.name: direction
